wargame.map

Class Map

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractMap<K,V>
      • java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,java.util.ArrayList<MapElement>>>
        • wargame.map.Map
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.util.Map<java.lang.Integer,java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,java.util.ArrayList<MapElement>>>

    public class Map
extends java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,java.util.ArrayList<MapElement>>>
implements java.io.Serializable
    This class represents two sets of MapElement associated to their position.
    The first hash set (Map) contains the positions that are rounded to fit exactly one square.
    The second one (contained into Map, invisible, named realPositions) contains the exact positions of each sprite. It is used to the display. x and y are stored conversely to the first map, in order to display upper sprites first.
    The first hash set (Map) is useful to know if a square is walkable, swimmable... so, it is used for the path finding, and to know if a character can move one a square.
    The second one is useful for the display: sprites do not have to be on a specific square, graphically speaking. It can be under two or more squares.
    More simply, the Map looks like the following hash map: { pos_x : { pos_y : [ elements having position (pos_x;pos_y) ] }, { pos_y_2 : [ elements having position (pos_x;pos_y_2) ] }, pos_x_2 : { pos_y : [ elements having position (pos_x_2;pos_y) ] }, { pos_y_2 : [ elements having position (pos_x_2;pos_y_2) ] } }
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • AStart

        private java.util.ArrayList<Position> AStart(int begin_x,
                                             int begin_y,
                                             int end_x,
                                             int end_y,
                                             java.lang.String methodName,
                                             java.util.ArrayList<Unit> units)
        This method implements The A* algorithm using the methodName method to know if a spot is crossable. It was implemented using the pseudocode from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm.
        Parameters:
        begin_x -
        begin_y -
        end_x -
        end_y -
        methodName -
        Returns:
        the list of position to go from the begin to the end positions.
